Posted: May 8, 2013
												Намного интереснее оригинальной GTA 4. Покупайте не задумываясь, две игры по цене одной это просто халява. Эти две новые истории сюжетно переплетаются с четвертой часть, но игра за каждого персонажа совсем разная. За Луиса Лопеса, помошника владельца клуба, придется окунуться в мир гламура и разврата, попутно избавляясь от конкурентов клуба и делать просто сумашедшие вещи, такие как угон вертолетов, растрел огромного катера, прыжки с парашютом, подрыв поездов и частных самолетоов для богатых. Игра за байкера тоже очень интересна, игра предстает перед нами в мрачном стиле. Много придется ездить на мотоциклах, участвовать в соревнованиях по арм реслингу и т.д. В игру добавили много нового оружия, более трехста новых песен и две новые радиостанции, а также много новых машин, вертолетов и мотоциклов. Вобщем игра бомба, по сравнению с оригинальной частью, это просто шедевр. Плюс, скучать вас не заставят новые режимы сетевой игры и разнообразные задания с драг диллерством. Моя оценка 10/10. P.S - Такие большие дополнения которые превращаются в полноценную игру - редкость.

												***Warning*** The game will not work on Windows 8 64bit (which I am running on my machine) when you install the game. The following instructions should help those who are having trouble launching the Grand Theft Games. This should help to play Grand Theft Auto Liberty City on Windows 8 64bit machines. To make the game playable, you have to remove "Microsoft Games for Windows - Live Redistributable" & Microsoft Games for Windows Marketplace from the Uninstall Programs. If you only see "Microsoft Games for Windows - Live Redistributable" in your uninstall list, that is fine. After removing the item(s), you have to go to http://www.xbox.com/en-NZ/Live/PC/DownloadClient and download Games for Windows Marketplace Client. Follow the onscreen instructions and create an account or log into your account. This app will allow you to play Grant Theft Auto VI & Episodes from Liberty City.

Posted: March 13, 2015
												Grand Theft Auto IV, a game that blew everyone's minds just because of the graphics. And then you realized San Andreas had way more to offer with less graphics. So what would be a solution to making a game seem so great with limited variety? Add some Downloadable Content that probably should of been in the game since Day One but at the same time make you feel like it is optional. Well I guess that's not entirely how Episodes of Liberty City was formed, just most DLC in general. Although this DLC I'll give some credit, you don't have to buy the original game to play it, which is pretty neat. Though makes you kind of wish all the content in Episodes of Liberty City would be indluded in the orignal game. I'll explain later on that but for now let's talk about the Episodes starting with the first one mostly everyone picked first, The Lost and the Damned. Okay maybe I picked it first.So the Lost and the Damned, what's it about. It's about a Biker named Johnny, who's no way related to a Greaser named Johnny back in another Rockstar game called "Bully," who all he wants is to ride with his Biker Gang and assist. The name of the Biker Gang is called "The Lost," who's runned by Billy who was in rehab for drugs. Supposably Johnny and Billy were great friends but since Billy's return it appears to not be as strong anymore. You even get a sense of betrayal is coming up. Well Spoiler Alert that's kind of what happens. The Lost and the Damned is basically Bully just shorten with blood and guns. Oh yes, the episode itself is not as long as the original game which is kind of dissapointing especially since these episodes are playable stand-alone. What's more the story of each episode takes place during the original game's timeline. So you would think there would be more going than just helping a mere Biker Gang with the Leader getting arrested all in attempt to get rid of Johnny. Though it may be short in story, it does add new weapons and do they play the part in a Biker Gang. From Automatic pistols to the classic sawed-off Shotgun. As you progress you'll gain other new weapons not seen in Grand Theft Auto IV, but since the story's short, it won't take long at all. Oh and Johnny has a problem playing dress-up. Yeah if you were thinking of making Johnny wear something other than a leather jacket for the whole game, I'm afraid that's not possible. Although I wouldn't mind the same kind of Jacket being worn by Niko Bellic, oh well next Episode.The other is known as "The Ballad of Gay Tony," and I won't lie, I thought you was going to play as Tony, but this Episode has the "Legend of Zelda Syndrom" meaning you play as another guy. And this guy is pretty much a Dominican Quagmire who goes by the name "Luis." Tony is the man you work for due to personal reasons that involve Luis' history with Tony. No nothing like that, more like Tony helpped Luis when Luis needed help though most. So Luis feels honorbound to help and work for Tony no matter what. Unlike The Lost episode, Ballad feels more lively. And it may not be as short as The Lost (though still far shorter than GTA IV) but there was much going on. Also like The Lost, this takes place during Grand Theft Auto IV's timeline, more specifically right after the Bank Robbery. You soon meet Tony and you're off to some meet, which ends up in a big fire fight trying to get out the door. Though this also introduces you to one of the new weapons in this Episode, but soon later in the game you realize both episodes have their own exclusive guns and weapons. As much I like The Lost in style, Ballad has my vote for most content. I mean there's a bunch of guns in it that really should have been in the original game from the start. But doesn't matter which one you like, it's an automatic hands down that the Shotgun in this game is Over Powered. Why? Explosive Rounds. The Ballad of Gay Tony is the only episode part of the GTA IV timeline that features Explosive Round ammunition. And boy could it do damage to EVERYTHING! Also early in the game you get to high jack a new Helicopter, a buzzard which unlike the orignal or the Lost features Rockets and Miniguns. The moment you started piloting it, you just didn't want off. Also Parachutes are in it. Guess what, they wasn't in Grand Theft Auto IV, big suprise. And where as Johnny didn't like playing dress-up Luis has no problems with it. Though doesn't like buying clothes so might as well wear what you have. I mentioned before how both of the episodes are part of the same timeline, What you might be wondering is what is Ballad's part of the story other than being bossed around by a gay guy. Well really this is the Episode that explains a bit on the whole Diamond thing that partially was around in Grand Theft Auto IV and as well in The Lost episode. But this shows how it started and how it ended which you know, I'm glad. I'm glad because those Diamonds seemed useless to the story in Grand Theft Auto IV to begin with, and the fact you didn't get them in the end was like "What was the point?" This Episode gives the point but I still think the Diamonds shouldn't of been a thing, but it works only for this Episode.Is Episodes of Liberty City worth getting? Not alone, I would get this along with Grand Theft Auto IV just to understand most of the story. Also with both episodes quite short in story, you may end up feel like "what else to do?" There is a Multiplayer option which has the same options in the orignal Grand Theft Auto IV, however customizing your character is more limited in customization. This is not a Bad DLC / game, just I wouldn't recommend buying it without getting the original. It's fun to play as a rage fueled biker along with a sex crazed bar manager. And the content given is very nice. But the Story length for both is not really enough to get this alone. Now if you are planning to get Grand Theft Auto IV, then yeah get this just to experience a little bit more.

												These two fairly-short campaigns add back some of the more "video-gamey" elements that were missing in the main game.   And the friend system is much, much better. No more phone calls, dates with your friends are completely optional, and you still get the bonuses they provide (mobile gun shop, mission backup, free cars, etc.). Unfortunately you're married to your chopper in The Lost and the Damned, but The Ballad of Gay Tony is much more open-minded when it comes to what vehicle you choose to drive.Still has the same optimization issues as GTA IV, but still playable if you launch the game outside of Steam (directly from LaunchEFLC.exe).

												Well, even with thermal throttling on my CPU this game performed really well, with a Fx-8350 and a GTX 760 runs perfectly 60fps steady as long as I know 'cause I've the V-Sync on, anyways, after talking about the PC Port stuff I'd like to review the actual game:This game has a nostalgia factor on me so I actually don't mind to see worse graphics than GTA 5, I originally played this expansions when they were Xbox 360 exclusive, those were good times, anyways, this is being sold as a new game here on steam, (Something that I totally understand) but as I consider them DLC's they have a BIGGER value for me, I mean, new weapons, really good storylines, TBOGT has some of the funniest misions on the GTA series at all, Liberty City is a place full of life, of course now it doesn't seem that good if we compare it to GTA 5 but, this game is different, is the latest great Grand Theft Auto game, I don't mean that GTA 5 is a bad game, of course I don't, I'm just saying that GTA 5 doesn't feel the classic way, it's almost perfect technically, not like a game that was trying to innovate, GTA 5 perfects everything which is good but GTA 4 and EFLC were trying to make people get excited, this is not objetive at all, but, if you like the old GTA style this is the best version you'll have, playing this game is like taking a whiff from the old times.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												As I mentioned in my review for the main game: This is an atrocious mess. Not just on Windows 10, either. This is designed to be a headache right out of the box on any version of Windows.I'll leave a brief summary of what I had to do to get this working: First off right-click the game title in the Steam library (not in Windoes Explorer like I initially did), click properties, and in 'launch options' put this line: -nomemrestrict -norestrictions ...that will make the game accept modern resolutions without crashing your computer. Then you'll want to take care of the GFWL crisis BEFORE YOU EVEN START THE GAME OTHERWISE YOU WON'T BE ABLE TO SAVE! (and they don't even warn you that you need to be logged into GFWL ahead of time, not even a whisper). Go to this site http://gtaforums.com/topic/388658-relgtaiv-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥/ and download the first link. Unrar that item and copy all those files to the game files of both GTA IV and the expansions. That should delete GFWL from being mandatory for saving.Rockstar Social Club also has a failing login but it seems you can play the game without it, so just opt to 'play offline' and you're good to go. Unless you want to play multiplayer, then I have no freaking clue what you'll need to do. :\

Posted: November 13, 2016
												Note: You MUST install "X Live Less" (without the spaces, Steam blocks the word for some reason. Google it, first link) to play this game. GFWL has discontinued and it is impossible to get past the authentication check without  "X Live Less".Did you like GTA4 and wanted more? And not quite ready for GTA5 yet or just loved Liberty City? Well this is for you. Definitely play the base GTA4 first as the events in this game are concurrent to GTA4, with the characters making cameos and references to the main story. Really this is two seperate stories in one, The Lost and the Damned, and The Ballad of Gay Tony. The Lost and the Damned has you leading a motorcycle gang through gang wars, fighting off the government from trying to shut you down and dealing with lots of drugs. You better get used to driving a motorcycle, you'll be on it a lot. At least they made you "stickier" now, used to fly off when hitting a pebble in GTA4. It's really a fairly tragic story, I won't ruin it but it shows that gang life is tough, brutal, and destroys everyone's life. It is a fun story with plenty of action, and a shoot and destroy everything final mission.The Ballad of Gay Tony is, well, much more fun than TLOU. You're Luis Lopez, helping your business partner Gay Tony (the game makes it quite clear that Luis is very straight, women falling over themselves to have him and he doesn't say no) keep your club afloat while short muscleheads, Russians and other gangs come to collect the debts you owe for the money you borrowed to run the Club. Plus you meet a very crass, very loud, very obnoxious, very, very rich arab man who loves guns, sex, and things money can't buy, who sets you on missions to steal outrageous things in some of the most fun missions in GTA. Seriously Yusuf missions are a treat. The only real negative of TBOGT which does hurt it some are all the helicopter missions, there's a disproportionate amount and the helicopter conrols and camera are just awful. Fortunately the missions aren't too hard, but I hate them nonetheless for the terrible controls. The story is compelling, and makes you race from one mission to the next. If you can only play this or TLOU, play this. All in all TLOU takes about 7 hours, TBOGT takes about 10 hours (assuming you only do the story missions), and are quite fun. The graphics more or less hold up today, though I still sometimes get 15 fps dips even with my Titan X and i7-6800k, odd. I do recommend the CryENB v3 for a bit better graphics. Enjoy the game, you won't regret it.8.9/10

Posted: December 19, 2014
												These two fairly-short campaigns add back some of the more "video-gamey" elements that were missing in the main game.   And the friend system is much, much better. No more phone calls, dates with your friends are completely optional, and you still get the bonuses they provide (mobile gun shop, mission backup, free cars, etc.). Unfortunately you're married to your chopper in The Lost and the Damned, but The Ballad of Gay Tony is much more open-minded when it comes to what vehicle you choose to drive.Still has the same optimization issues as GTA IV, but still playable if you launch the game outside of Steam (directly from LaunchEFLC.exe).

Posted: December 31, 2014
												A great expansion to the already amazing GTA IV.The Lost and Dammed was a good start, with a few new weapons and cars. The missions do complete the plot holes in the original GTA IV, so it is a must play if you want to get the full picture of Nicko's story. However, without spoiling much, it is a very drepessing story and overall environment. On the other hand, the Ballad of Gay Tony is, not surprisingly, more colorfull. It's all about going to parties, out in the night, score chicks, have fun, an environment that pleases me more. I also prefer the main character to the one in the Lost and Dammed.Again, these two episodes complete GTA IV.

I literally played nothing of this NOR GTA IV, and yet my hours show as if I've played them. This to me is Fraud. I tried to explain the situation but It's just a huge headache and waste of time and money. I implore you to avoid ANY of the GTA IV franchise on PC. Including the Episodes. It will not work and you won't be able to return it because once you install it and run it just for it to crash, your hours will add up like a broken taxi meter.

Posted: March 1, 2016
												“Man was born for society. However little He may be attached to the World, He never can wholly forget it, or bear to be wholly forgotten by it. Disgusted at the guilt or absurdity of Mankind, the Misanthrope flies from it: He resolves to become an Hermit, and buries himself in the Cavern of some gloomy Rock. While Hate inflames his bosom, possibly He may feel contented with his situation: But when his passions begin to cool; when Time has mellowed his sorrows, and healed those wounds which He bore with him to his solitude, think you that Content becomes his Companion? Ah! no, Rosario. No longer sustained by the violence of his passions, He feels all the monotony of his way of living, and his heart becomes the prey of Ennui and weariness. He looks round, and finds himself alone in the Universe: The love of society revives in his bosom, and He pants to return to that world which He has abandoned. Nature loses all her charms in his eyes: No one is near him to point out her beauties, or share in his admiration of her excellence and variety. Propped upon the fragment of some Rock, He gazes upon the tumbling waterfall with a vacant eye, He views without emotion the glory of the setting Sun. Slowly He returns to his Cell at Evening, for no one there is anxious for his arrival; He has no comfort in his solitary unsavoury meal: He throws himself upon his couch of Moss despondent and dissatisfied, and wakes only to pass a day as joyless, as monotonous as the former.” ― Matthew Gregory Lewis, The Monk
